question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the generated code is executable for demonstration. Create HTML code for a coal company's ERP system with an elegant interface, complete components, visualization elements, and comprehensive professional functionalities.

checklist.title: Is the ERP system architecture properly structured?
checklist.description: Examine whether the HTML code implements a proper SPA (Single Page Application) architecture with clear module separation (HR, Finance, Inventory, Production, etc.) and navigation framework. Check for clean component hierarchy with parent-child relationships. Score 0 if there's no clear architecture, 5 if basic module separation exists but lacks proper navigation, and 10 if the architecture follows industry standards with proper routing and state management.

checklist.title: Does the interface include essential coal industry ERP components?
checklist.description: Verify that the HTML includes coal-specific components: resource tracking dashboards, mine production monitoring, coal quality analysis charts, equipment maintenance schedules, and regulatory compliance tools. Each missing critical component costs 2 points. Deduct 5 points if key visualizations (production trend graphs, equipment utilization charts) are absent. Award full 10 points only if all core coal industry modules are present and functionally connected.

checklist.title: Are data visualization elements implemented effectively?
checklist.description: Evaluate the quality of data visualization elements: coal production graphs, inventory level charts, financial dashboards, and operational KPIs. Check whether the visualizations use appropriate chart types for different data categories (bar charts for production comparison, line charts for trends, heat maps for resource allocation). Deduct 3 points if visualizations aren't interactive, 2 points if they use inappropriate chart types, and 2 points if they lack legends or tooltips. Full score requires responsive visualizations with proper data encoding.

checklist.title: Is there an integrated dashboard for operational oversight?
checklist.description: Assess whether the ERP system includes a comprehensive dashboard that aggregates critical metrics (coal extraction rates, equipment downtime, inventory levels, workforce allocation, safety incidents) for executive decision-making. The dashboard should include real-time alerts, filterable data views, and customizable displays. Deduct 5 points if the dashboard lacks data integration across departments, 3 points if it doesn't support filtering/customization, and 2 points if it lacks export functionality. Full score requires a complete executive dashboard with drill-down capabilities.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as data loading failures, form validation errors, offline operation, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should implement form validation, data sanitization, graceful error handling, and fallback UI states. Award 10 points for comprehensive error handling, 5 points for basic validation only, and 0 points if exceptions aren't managed at all.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-powered coal demand prediction 2. Real-time equipment maintenance alerts with augmented reality integration 3. Environmental impact visualization dashboard 4. Interactive mine mapping). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple dashboard widgets showing the same data) 2. Function modules unrelated to coal industry ERP (e.g., built-in games or entertainment features) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary 3D animations or auto-playing videos). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data models/views/controllers), component reusability, code maintainability, and accessibility standards. Check for semantic HTML usage, ARIA attributes for accessibility, proper CSS organization (preferably using CSS modules or a framework), and clean JavaScript with minimal global variables. Deduct 5 points for accessibility failures, 3 points for non-semantic markup, and 2 points for poor code organization. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern enterprise UI principles: 1) Consistent color scheme appropriate for industrial applications (primarily neutral colors with strategic accent colors) 2) Clear visual hierarchy with proper whitespace utilization 3) Professional typography system (readable fonts at appropriate sizes) 4) Uniform UI components following a design system. Deduct 3 points for inconsistent styling, 5 points for poor information hierarchy, and 2 points for cluttered layouts. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactive elements provide appropriate feedback: 1) Loading states for async operations 2) Clear button states (hover, active, disabled) 3) Smooth transitions between views 4) Appropriate form validation feedback 5) Responsive design for different screen sizes. Deduct 3 points for missing loading indicators, 2 points for abrupt transitions, 3 points for poor mobile adaptation, and 2 points for inadequate interactive feedback. The full score is 10 points.
